LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Kingdom of Tonga 
 
  The Proposal  A loan is proposed for the Economic and Public Sector 
Reform Program (EPSRP) to support reform measures in 
public finance and the public service.   
The Program   
Rationale    The national strategic vision of the Kingdom of Tonga has 
as its key objective the attainment of a higher standard of 
living for all Tongans. Achievement of this objective has 
been limited by low long-term economic growth rates, and 
by employment growth well below the rate of increase of 
the  labor  force.  These  disappointing  outcomes  reflect 
policy  and  governance  environments  that  have 
discouraged private sector investment, and the crowding- 
out effects of a relatively large public sector. Government 
finances are deteriorating due to inadequate collection of 
nontax revenue, transfers to public sector enterprises, and 
unbudgeted  spending.  Wages  and  salaries  account  for 
over  57%  of  current  expenditure,  crowding  out 
expenditures on goods, services, and investments.   
 
Various  changes  addressing  these  issues  have  already 
taken  place,  which  are  in  line  with  the  prioritized 
development  objectives  and  policies  established  in  the 
Seventh  Strategic  Development  Plan,  2001-2003.  The 
Government  is  now  actively  seeking  to  accelerate  the 
reform process by implementing the EPSRP.  
 
Objectives and Scope  The  objective  of  the  EPSRP  is  to  ensure  overall 
macroeconomic  stability  and  to  contribute  to  enhanced 
private sector-led economic growth.   
 
The EPSRP comprises two main areas of reform: (i) fiscal 
reform measures aimed at achieving a sustainable fiscal 
balance and (ii) public service reform measures seeking to 
improve public service delivery to the private sector and the 
general public.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed 
loan to the Kingdom of Tonga for the Economic and Public Sector Reform Program (EPSRP). 
The Report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Building a Performance-
Based Public Service, and if the proposed loan is approved by the Board, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, shall approve the TA.  
 
II.  INTRODUCTION 
2.  Discussions  between  the  Government  of  the  Kingdom  of  Tonga  and  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  on  developing  the  EPSRP  have  been  ongoing  since  1998.  In 
response  to  the  Government's  request  for  TA1  to  formulate  the  proposed  EPSRP,  ADB 
submitted a draft concept paper, including the institutional framework for EPSRP management, 
to the Government in August 1999. The Cabinet of Ministers approved the draft concept paper 
in  April  2000.  The  Prime  Minister  reiterated  the  Government’s  commitment  to  the  reform 
program in a public statement made in June 2001. The TA to prepare the EPSRP and to 
facilitate the initial stage of implementation commenced in September 2001. A consultation 
mission  was  fielded  during  15-20  October  2001,  and  a  fact-finding  mission  during  24 
November–8 December 2001, followed by a preappraisal mission during 21-26 January 2002.2 
In preparation for the EPSRP, the Cabinet approved  a number of submissions, including all of 
those designated as first tranche conditions, on 23 January 2002.3  
 
3.  All reform measures have been in preparation for an extended period of 1-4 years. 
Moving  forward  now  is  spurred  by  a  number  of  factors—a  worsening  fiscal  situation, 
disappointing economic growth, and the eroded Tonga Trust Fund—which have led to  a 
specific “macroeconomic moment” where macroeconomic vulnerability creates not just a need 
for borrowing but an increased understanding of the need for reform. The Government has 
taken the initiative to compile these reform measures into a coherent  reform program, and has 
established an organizational structure and a secretariat to ensure its implementation.  The 
program logical framework (Appendix 1) and the draft policy matrix (Appendix 2) are a result of 
these  efforts  and  were  discussed  with  senior  government  officials,  private  sector 
representatives, and other key stakeholders. Focus group discussions, hearings and workshops 
involving  civil  society  were  organized,  are  still  ongoing,  and  will  continue  during  the 
implementation of the EPSRP. The program logical framework and the policy matrix outline the 
content of the EPSRP, which forms part of the Government’s overall reform program. The 
comprehensive policy agenda and reform priorities of the Government go beyond the EPSRP 
and are summarized in the development policy letter (DPL) from the minister of finance found in 
Appendix 3.

III.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
A.  Background and Recent Economic Performance 
    
4.  The Tongan economy grew at an average annual rate of 1.8% during 1973-1995, with 
per capita gross domestic product (GDP) growth at 1.2%. The engine of growth was remittances 
from Tongan workers overseas.4 Real government spending also grew strongly. Real GDP grew 
at an average annual rate of 2.2% in the 7-year period from 30 June 1994 to 30 June 2001; but 
growth rates ranged from - 0.2% (FY1996) to 6.2% (FY2000). The budget statement for FY2002 
observed that the average annual growth for FY1998-FY2000 was estimated at 6.1% in nominal 
terms  and  4.4%  in  real  terms.  This  performance  represents  a  marked  recovery  from  the 
recession over the FY1996-FY1997 period, when minimal growth was recorded. The turnaround 
in FY2000 was attributed largely to growth in the services sector (5.6%) supported by recovery 
in  the  agriculture  and  fishery  sector,  which  grew  by  10.8%.  The  impact  of  millennium 
celebrations was a feature of this period, with a 17.9% growth rate in the commerce, restaurant, 
and hotel sectors. Government administration and community services became the largest 
sector in the monetary economy by the turn of the 21st  century, growing at an average annual 
rate of 5.0%, and accounting for 15.3% of GDP in FY2001. This sector was a major contributor 
to growth through the 1990s and into the new millennium. Economic indicators suggest that 
GDP growth for FY2001 is likely to be in the order of 6% in nominal terms and 3% in real terms. 
The anticipated real growth in GDP in FY2002 was projected in June 2001 as 3% with some 
potential for improvement.5 
   
5.  However, the forecast for FY2002 was revised downward in December 2001 to 1.5% as 
a result of deteriorating world economic conditions. The impact of tropical cyclone Waka that 
devastated the northern island group of Vava’u and the Niuas on 31 December 2001 would 
lower this further. Workers’ remittances contribute about half of Tonga’s foreign exchange 
earnings, and about 60% of these flows come from thousands of Tongans living in the United 
States. In addition, disruption to international air services has diminished fresh fish exports to 
Hawaii. There will be negative effects on government revenue as expenditure for imported 
goods is affected by these developments. It is also clear that short-term reform measures for 
increasing revenues and reducing expenditures that had been foreseen in June-July 2001 will 
not have much impact in FY2002.  
 
6.  Government finances deteriorated from a fiscal deficit of 0.2% of GDP in FY1999, to 0.4 
% in FY2000 and 2.6% in FY2001 (Figure 1). The fiscal rule that recurrent expenditure should 
not exceed recurrent revenue was adhered to, but led to a reduction in nonwage expenditures 
to accommodate the increasing wage bill. With the 20% public service wage increase in 2000, 
wages and salaries now account for over 57% of current expenditure, crowding out expenditure 
on other goods and services and limiting the availability of domestic resources for investment. 
Disappointing collection of nontax revenue, transfers to public sector enterprises (PSEs), and 
unbudgeted spending, including a loan to the national airline, caused total public expenditure to 
run ahead of budget estimates for FY2002. In addition, there is an estimated T$30 million 
unfunded liability arising from the public servants’ retirement scheme introduced in 1999. Until 
mid-2001 the Government drew resources from the Tonga Trust Fund6 to cover any emerging

8.  The external accounts were characterized by large trade deficits throughout the 1990s, 
large net private transfer flows, and a negative current account balance that often reflected 
foreign borrowing to finance public investment projects. The decline in official foreign reserves

moved from surplus to deficit, reflecting a decline in tourism receipts, a rise in transportation

9.  Tonga has enjoyed relatively buoyant growth in recent years at least partly as a result of 
an  expansionary  fiscal  and  monetary  policy.  However,  the  country  now  faces  balance  of 
payments  difficulties  and  rising  inflation.  Both  of  these  threats  are  serious,  and  neither  is 
susceptible to a short-term solution. Even in the face of severe restraint, foreign exchange 
reserves would take some time to recover from the current situation of less than 2 months of 
import cover to a more comfortable 4-6 months, which was the case in the past. Inflation will put 
further pressure on an overstretched budget. The most immediate of these pressures will likely 
be for further adjustments to the public service wage scale, which was adjusted upwards by 
20% in FY2001. Virtually the whole of this increase will have been offset by inflation by the end 
of the current fiscal year. 
 
10.  It is fair to say that the existence of the Tonga Trust Fund and remittances from Tongan 
overseas workers have masked  economic reality in Tonga for a long time. That reality is 
sluggish growth, a public sector that is large in relation to the economy, and heavy dependence 
on the Government for job creation. Reform is needed to address these structural problems 
while remittances still continue to underpin a weak domestic economy. 
 
B.  Macroeconomic Issues and Prospects 
 
11.  At the time of its annual Article IV consultation in June 2001, the International Monetary 
Fund (IMF) was critical of the expansionary fiscal and monetary policies pursued in FY2001. 
The overall fiscal deficit for FY2001 was then estimated at 2% of GDP and now stands at 1.5%. 
It was also observed that despite a rise in the reserve requirement from 12% to 15% in 
September 2000, excess liquidity, coupled with the low interest paid on NRBT short-term bills, 
had facilitated strong credit expansion by banks. IMF prescriptions stressed the importance of 
fiscal and monetary tightening and early implementation of corresponding measures to regain 
external viability. 
 
12.  Economic growth in FY2002 is unlikely to come up to expectations established before 
the events of 11 September 2001 and before the extent of the world economic slowdown 
became evident. Remittances are vulnerable to the shock of possible job losses in the ranks of 
expatriate Tongans.  Imports will decline should there be lower remittances, and consequently 
government revenues, which are largely import related, will fall. Exports of niche agricultural 
products may be affected, and some bank assets weakened. 
 
13.  The leisurely pace of reform in recent years is no longer compatible with the reality that 
fiscal balance has been lost and monetary policy has few effective instruments at its disposal. It 
should be stressed that these endemic problems are structural rather than cyclical. There are 
two principal structural problems:

5
   
(i)  The Government has been active in almost every field of economic endeavor. In 
addition to public utilities, communications, and transportation (both marine and 
air), the Government is involved in fishing, tourism, retail trade, and many other 
aspects of economic life that are not normally regarded as traditional areas of 
government activity even in small economies. It is essential that these activities 
be rationalized by closure, divestiture, or corporatization in order to stem losses 
or recycle resources into more productive uses. This will take considerable time, 
since almost none of these endeavors are saleable in their present form, and 
changes  will  involve  disruption  of  established  patterns  of  employment  and 
economic activity that underpin the social sector. Moreover, capital markets are 
virtually non-existent in Tonga, so privatization will involve foreign ownership or a 
long wait until the State can realize its investment. 
 
(ii)  The Government has become the largest employer by far, with nearly 5,000 paid 
positions accounting for over one third of total paid employment. Employment in 
PSEs adds nearly another 2,000 employees and raises the total government 
share of paid employment to about 45%. This level of employment has meant 
that  budgetary  restraint  has  bitten  more  deeply  into  nonwage  and  salary 
operating costs so that the relatively large government labor force is not provided 
with adequate funds to be effective in all cases. Wages and salaries now account 
for over 57% of government operating costs net of debt service. Rebalancing is 
clearly needed. 
 
14.  These two structural problems continue to place a heavy burden on the government 
budget, a situation that has become untenable. Given the unsatisfactory collection of tax and 
nontax revenue due to legislative loopholes and a weak revenue administration, government 
revenue falls far below what it should amount to.  
 
15.  Until recently these structural issues were not perceived as actual problems.  It is only 
now, with the worsening fiscal situation, disappointing economic growth, and eroded Tonga 
Trust Fund, that addressing these structural problems has become a priority. Economic and 
public sector reforms are now fundamental to Tonga’s prospects for economic growth in the 
years ahead. Unlike the governments of other Pacific developing member countries (PDMCs), 
the Government of Tonga has a stable political climate, and to this extent has an advantage in 
being able to see a reform program through.  
 
C.  Government Objectives and Strategy 
 
16.  The Government of Tonga’s development objectives and strategy are presented in the 
cabinet-approved Seventh Strategic Development Plan, 2001-2003 (SSDP). The Plan identifies 
a sustained rise in living standards as the overall development objective, with living standards 
defined in terms of both income and human development levels. The basic means of achieving 
this development objective is durable economic growth, which generates economic benefits that 
are shared equitably and permits higher expenditure on education and health. More specifically, 
the Plan aims to promote (i) a well-educated and skilled labor force; (ii) efficient, well-structured 
PSEs; (iii) a sound enabling environment for private sector-led economic growth; (iv) an efficient 
and  well-structured  government  sector;  (v)  well-maintained  physical  infrastructure;  (vi) 
conservation of the environment and efficient use of renewable resources; (vii) participation of 
civil  society  and  the  community  in  economic  development;  (viii) equitable  distribution  of

6   
development  benefits;  (ix)  low  crime  rate  and  enhanced  national  security;  and  (x) stable 
macroeconomic environment. 
 
17.  The Government  acknowledges that, for durable growth to occur, the bulk of investment 
should occur in the private sector of a market economy in which the Government will play a 
number of crucial, complementary roles. These roles are providing a stable macroeconomic 
environment,  promoting  education  and  technology,  investing  in  physical  and  institutional 
infrastructure, providing a social safety net for vulnerable groups, and preventing environmental 
degradation. Therefore, the SSDP gives top priority for funding purposes to a restructuring 
program that is designed to (i) make the Tongan economy more competitive and dynamic, (ii) 
facilitate and promote the growth of the private sector, (iii) rationalize and raise the efficiency of 
the Government and public sector enterprises, and  (iv) mobilize domestic saving to raise self- 
reliance in financing investments. The Government’s overall reform agenda, as outlined in the 
DPL, comprises four reform areas: (i) fiscal reform, (ii) public sector reform, (iii) financial sector 
reform, and (iv) private sector reform. While the EPSRP focuses on fiscal and public sector 
reform, the Government will also implement the following additional reform measures.  
 
18.  The  objective  of  the  financial  sector  reform  is  to  improve  overall  financial  sector 
performance by (i) improving the effectiveness of monetary policy and management, and (ii) 
enhancing financial intermediation of the Tonga Development Bank. The SSDP identifies two 
main issues that must be addressed if monetary policy is to better contribute to the maintenance 
of macroeconomic stability. The first is NRBT’s weak balance sheet, which currently prevents 
the effective use of indirect monetary policy instruments.7 The second issue concerns the need 
to strengthen NRBT’s supervisory capacity in line with the provisions of the Financial Institutions 
Act  of  1991  and  subsequent  amendments,  in  order  to  ensure  adequate  enforcement  of 
prudential regulations covering all financial institutions. In accordance with a cabinet decision of 
23 January 2002, NRBT is responsible for implementation of the financial sector reform and will 
set up a reform team under the reform secretariat. 
 
19.  Acceleration  of  private  sector-led  economic  growth—the  objective  of  policy  reforms 
aimed at encouraging private sector growth—will be addressed through (i) improving the legal 
and regulatory framework for local and foreign investment, and (ii) introducing and progressively 
implementing tax reform. The keys to promoting private sector development are transparency 
and predictability of the business climate. This depends on replacing the discretionary powers of 
bureaucrats and ministers in regard to  business licensing with a clear statement of policy and 
streamlined procedures. A new foreign investment act has been drafted with assistance from 
the Foreign Investment Advisory Service (FIAS), and will be introduced into the Legislative 
Assembly in the 2002 session. The business climate will also benefit from the removal of 
ambiguity and discretion in matters such as the granting of work and residence visas. Reform 
measures  in  support  of  private  sector  development  include  (i)  formulation  of  a  national 
investment policy, including the determination of sectors in which foreign investors can invest; 
(ii) passage of the new foreign investment act; (iii) repeal of import licenses and the  Industrial 
Development Incentives Act with clear transitional provisions; and (iv) review of land lease 
regulations.

IV.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Background and Rationale

standard of living for all Tongans. Achievement of this objective has been limited by a low long-

private  sector  investment,  and  the  crowding-out  effects  of  a  relatively  large  public  sector.

macroeconomic  moment,  where  macroeconomic  vulnerability  creates  not  just  a  need  for

B.  Objectives and Scope 
 
32.   The objective of the EPSRP is to ensure overall macroeconomic stability and to contribute 
to enhanced private sector-led economic growth. Preconditions for reaching this objective are (i) 
achieving a sustainable fiscal balance, and (ii) improving the efficiency and effectiveness of 
service delivery by the public sector.  
 
33.  The Government’s overall reform program comprises four main areas of reform: (i) fiscal 
reform, (ii) public service reform, (iii) financial sector reform, and (iv) private sector reform. The 
EPSRP focuses on two of these reform areas: (i) fiscal reform measures aimed at achieving a 
sustainable  fiscal  balance  through  (a)  strengthening  public  expenditure  management,  (b) 
enhancing revenue generation, and (c) improving the efficiency and effectiveness of resource 
use in the public enterprise sector; and (ii) public service reform measures that seek to improve 
public service delivery to the private sector and the general public by means of (a) establishing 
the institutional framework for a performance-oriented public service, and (b) promoting efficient 
and effective performance management.  
    
34.  The  EPSRP,  through  these  two  reform  areas,  will  build  the  legal  and  regulatory 
framework and the institutional capacity to achieve macroeconomic stability and, combined with 
financial sector and private sector reform, to contribute to accelerated economic growth.

36.  The key to achieving sustainable fiscal balance in the short term consists of a strong 
government commitment to the reform process and a “top down” approach to budget making. 
The former involves regular meetings at the Cabinet level to supervise the reform process. The 
latter begins with developing a credible medium-term fiscal framework that is used to provide 
overall spending limits for all government-sponsored activity, including forward estimates for at 
least three years beyond the current budget year. In the medium term, the minister of finance 
needs the legislative authority to manage the budget execution process. Here the key feature is 
commitment control to ensure that government spending can adapt to changing circumstances, 
and to ensure that government departments have limited ability to spend beyond agreed upon 
budget caps.  
 
37.  The current revenue administration is operating below desirable standards.  With limited 
computerization, an inadequate number of experienced staff, and lack of training, combined with 
the  absence  of  a  comprehensive  and  appropriate  set  of  legislative  provisions  to  enforce 
compliance, the administration is not in a position to effectively administer either the current 
legislation  or  the  proposed  system  of  taxes.  The  Government  estimates  US$5  million  in 
outstanding taxes, and it is suggested that an effective audit program would reveal an even 
larger amount.17 Hence, there is an urgent need for the tax administration to be strengthened in 
order both to improve revenues under the current tax regime and pave the way for tax reform. 
However the benefit of increased revenues from improved tax administration will only come 
towards the end of 2003 and thereafter, when capacity for audit and compliance enforcement is 
enhanced through hiring and training of new staff and centralizing tax administration into one 
location.  
 
38.  The proposed initial improvements to the tax regime include a new legislative basis for 
tax collection and training of staff, particularly in audit and compliance procedures. This system 
has to be put in place well in advance of the proposed new tax system to allow for the 
development of the administration prior to the major challenges created by a new tax system. 
The  legislative  changes  to  be  coupled  with  a  general  modernization  of  current  provisions 
include: (i) redesigning the objection/appeals process, (ii) redesigning the penalties regime, (iii) 
provision for seizure and sale of assets to recover outstanding debts, and (iv) introduction of the 
World Trade Organization (WTO) valuation system.

D.  Social and Environmental Issues 
 
1.  Social  and Poverty Impact 
 
51.  Tonga  has  achieved  relatively  high  social  indicators  as  a  result  of  government 
investments in social sectors and service provision over the past 30 years. The constrained 
fiscal situation will have short and medium-term implications for the provision of all government 
services if reform measures designed to regain fiscal balance are not introduced within the near 
future. With the implementation of the public service reform, aimed at increasing the efficiency 
and effectiveness of the public service, it is anticipated that service delivery to the general public 
will improve in the medium term.  
 
52.  The major socioeconomic impacts over the next 2-3 years are likely be a reduction in 
income of approximately 500 or more households, mainly in the capital, Nuku’alofa, due to the 
enforcement  of  the  retirement  age,  early  voluntary  retirement,  or  retrenchment  with 
compensation. Lump sum payments are unlikely to provide long-term social security for retirees. 
Households depending on a single income from a public sector employee who retires or is 
retrenched will be the most vulnerable, especially those on a low salary scale and/or where the 
household has limited access to land. Amendments of the current tax and customs legislation 
will enable the Government to collect unpaid taxes and duties. It is safe to assume that the 
majority of the outstanding taxes are owed by private enterprises and  high-income earners.  
 
53.  Assuming that Tonga’s strong customs of family assistance will cushion the impact of 
reduced public sector expenditure and provide traditional social safety net functions, the high 
dependency ratio will continue to rise. Currently about 20% of the population provide for the 
other 80%. Those in employment in Tonga will have increased financial obligations, and the 
demand on relatives working overseas will increase.  
 
54.  To mitigate the negative impact of rightsizing, the EPSRP includes social safety net 
arrangements. Efforts will be made to ensure that the population of the outer islands will not be 
affected disproportionately. Affected staff (voluntary early retirees and involuntary redundancies) 
will receive separation payments and will have access to counseling and training to be arranged 
by the economic and social impact monitoring unit under the Prime Minister’s Office (PMO). 
This includes community-based financial management training, and technical and business 
training  to  mitigate  the  overall  social  and  gender  impacts  of  affected  staff  (paras.  55-57). 
Detailed retrenchment plans will be prepared by departments. The plans will be reviewed by the 
economic  and  social  impact  monitoring  unit  for  consistency  with  the  principles  of  equity 
considerations and protection of the vulnerable as expressed in the ADB Social Protection 
Strategy.24 Mitigation measures will include provisions to ensure that women, public servants in 
the outer islands, and other affected workers vulnerable to poverty (i) will have equal opportunity 
to participate in the training programs and avail of small business opportunities, and (ii) will not 
be impoverished by the retrenchment.  
 
55.  The proportion of women in public sector employment may decline, and low-paid female 
clerical workers are likely to be the most vulnerable to retrenchment. Reduction in public sector 
employment opportunities and possible cuts to expenditure on secondary education are likely to 
increase  the  number  of  unemployed  young  people.  Self-employment  will  be  an  option  for 
women  and  unemployed  youth,  which  will  be  facilitated  through  short-term  business  and 
technical skills training.

56.  An efficient and performance-oriented public service will have positive social impacts by 
improving the quality of government services to the public. However, Tonga already has a deficit 
of skilled and professional people in the health and postsecondary technical training sectors. It 
is very likely that these skilled public servants will opt for early retirement, seek opportunities 
abroad, and join the ranks of Tongan migrants. It is therefore essential that reform measures 
include incentives to retain government employees with essential skills. These comprise (i) 
introduction  of  performance-based  contracts  for  heads  of  departments  and  senior  public 
servants, (ii) revision of the current remuneration policy, and (iii) introduction of a merit-based 
pay policy.   
 
57.  Anticipated  private  sector  growth  will  increase  jobs  and  opportunities  for  self-
employment and will in turn reduce youth unemployment.  However this requires that post-
secondary training be more closely matched to labor market demands in Tonga than is currently 
the case.  
 
58.  Social monitoring and public consultation constitute a key element in the reform process. 
A Tongan participatory/public relations specialist25 is assisting the Government in a broad-based 
consultative process that engages members of the public sector, the private sector, and civil 
society through workshops and seminars targeting specific groups (politicians, public sector 
officials, chamber of commerce, churches, nongovernment organizations [NGOs]) and hearings 
that bring together representatives of the Government, the business community, NGOs, and the 
general public. Further details on the social and poverty impact are in Appendix 4.  
 
2.  Mitigation Measures  
 
59.  In  addition  to  financial  compensation  packages  for  voluntary  early  retirees  and 
redundancies,  a  range  of  nonfinancial  mitigation  measures  will  be  available.  Many  public 
servants taking early retirement will still be potentially economically active, and some will have 
skills and experience that will make them attractive to private sector employers.  However, a 
large number of civil servants who retire or are retrenched will be in the low-pay, low-skill 
category. The Government is concerned about the future of people in this group.  A number of 
retraining options will be available. Training needs assessments will be carried out by the 
economic and social impact monitoring unit after the staffing plans have been prepared by each 
department.  Funds  have  been  earmarked  from  the  proceeds  of  the  loan  to  ensure  that 
counterpart funds are available for these mitigation measures.  
 
60.  There is broad agreement from the private sector that two types of skills are in demand: 
(i) bookkeeping/basic accounting and the use of simple accounting software packages; and (ii) 
word processing and spreadsheet computer applications, and office automation. These possible 
job opportunities are of particular interest  mainly to clerical staff, who will be encouraged to 
participate  in  training  offering  these  skills.  Other  training  options  include  small  business 
management, technical skills and horticulture. A number of NGOs and government training 
institutions  are  offering  short-term  vocational  training  courses.  These  institutions  will  be 
engaged by the  economic and social impact monitoring unit to carry out tailor-made programs 
(see Appendix 4).

V.  THE PROPOSED LOAN 
A.  Amount of Loan and Source of Funds 
 
63.  The Government has asked ADB to provide a loan of US$10 million equivalent from its 
Special Funds resources to support economic and public sector reforms. The size of the loan is 
based on the scope and costs of (i) fiscal reforms, and (ii) public service reforms. It takes into 
account the importance and urgency of these reforms, and the availability of funding for the 
Government’s overall reform program. The total funds required for the reform measures amount to 
US$15.2 million over the period 2002-2004. The proceeds from the program loan cover about 
66% of these financial adjustment costs.  
 
B.  Interest, Maturity, and Utilization Period 
 
64.  The loan will bear a 24-year maturity, including a grace period of 8 years, and 1% interest 
charge during the grace period and 1.5% thereafter. The loan is expected to be utilized over a 20-
month period.  
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
65.  MOF will be the Executing Agency for the EPSRP and will be responsible for its overall 
implementation. A fiscal reform team with five senior government officials will be established by 
MOF. The other key agency involved in the implementation of the Program is the PMO. A public 
sector reform team, led by the establishment office in the PMO, will be responsible for the 
coordination  and  implementation  of  these  reform  activities.  The  Government  established  a 
cabinet committee for reform in 2000, and the Cabinet approved the overall organizational 
structure  of  the  reform  program  and  the  EPSRP  on  23  January  2002.  This  includes  the 
establishment of a reform secretariat and the appointment of a senior public servant to head it. It 
will  also  have  additional  staff  and  necessary  resources,  acceptable  to  ADB.  Program 
implementation  will  be  coordinated  on  a  day-to-day  basis  by  the  secretariat  and  will  be 
undertaken by the two reform teams, which will report monthly to the Cabinet through the reform 
secretariat and the cabinet committee for reform. TA for implementation of the public service 
reform will be provided under the EPSRP  (see Appendix 5).

18  
 
D.  Procurement 
 
66.  In accordance with simplified disbursement procedures and related requirements for 
program loans,26 goods and services produced and originating in ADB member countries, other 
than those items specified on a negative list (Appendix 6) and imports financed by other bilateral 
and multilateral sources, will be procured in accordance with standard public sector procedures 
in the Kingdom of Tonga and normal commercial practices for procurement by the private 
sector,  acceptable  to  ADB.  ADB  has  ensured  that  standard  public  and  private  sector 
procurement  procedures  used  in  the  country  are  adequate  in  terms  of  competition  and 
efficiency. In the case of goods commonly traded on the international commodity markets, they 
will be procured in accordance with procedures appropriate to the trade and acceptable to ADB.  
 
E.  Disbursement 
 
67.  The proceeds of the loan will be disbursed only to finance the foreign exchange costs of 
a broad range of imports, subject to the negative list of ineligible items (Appendix 6). The loan 
will be disbursed on the basis of a certification provided by the Borrower confirming that, in each 
year in which EPSRP proceeds are expected to be disbursed, the value of total imports minus 
(i) imports from nonmember countries, (ii) ineligible imports, and (iii) imports financed under 
other official development assistance, will be equivalent to or greater than the amount expected 
to be disbursed during the year. ADB will have the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds 
and to verify the accuracy of the Borrower’s certification. 
 
F.  Counterpart Funds 
 
68.  Counterpart funds to be generated from the proceeds of the program loan will be used to 
finance part of the local currency costs relating to the implementation of the fiscal and public 
service reforms. The total financial adjustment costs include (i) US$1.5 million for improved tax 
administration, (ii) US$6.0 million for corporatization and privatization of selected government 
business activities, and (iii) US$7.7 million for public service reform. The loan proceeds of US$10 
million  equivalent  represent  about    66%  of  the  estimated  total  adjustment  costs  of  around 
US$15.2 million. To mitigate the anticipated impacts of public service reform, at least 20% of the 
counterpart funds have been earmarked to assist those affected. Although savings of around 
US$7 million are expected to result from reform activities supported by the proposed program 
loan, these benefits are anticipated to  materialize only towards the end of the loan period and 
thereafter; thus, they will help to enhance the sustainability of postreform fiscal balances. 
 
G.  Monitoring and Tranching 
 
69.  ADB will carry out periodic reviews of the progress of implementing the EPSRP, and will 
assess the impact of the Program on vulnerable groups and other sectors of the economy. 
Formal reviews will be undertaken jointly by the reform secretariat and ADB every 6 months. 
The Government will keep ADB informed of the outcome of the policy discussions with other 
multilateral and bilateral aid agencies that have implications for the implementation of the 
Program, and will provide ADB with the opportunity to comment on policy proposals by other 
major funding agencies.  The representatives of the Government, ADB, and other major funding 
agencies  for  the  EPSRP  will  meet  at  least  once  every  6  months  to  review  program 
implementation. The meetings will continue after the closing of the loan and will form part of the

VII.  PROGRAM BENEFITS AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
 
75.  The economic and public sector reforms supported by the Program will restore fiscal 
stability, increasing the efficiency of the public sector and creating a conducive environment for 
private  sector  growth.  Amendments  to  the  current  tax  and  customs  legislation  and  their 
enforcement by a strengthened tax administration will not only ensure that outstanding taxes,

21
estimated at US$5 million, will be collected, but will also help in achieving fiscal balance and 
improved service delivery. They will also ensure transparent and predictable taxation, reduce 
corrupt  practices,  and  subsequently  improve  the  investment  climate  in  Tonga.  The 
corporatization  of  government  business  activities  will  fully  expose  these  entities  to  market 
forces, ensuring efficient and cost-effective service delivery to their customers and creating 
equal conditions with private service providers. The EPSRP will help to achieve rightsizing of 
the public service, while improving its effectiveness and efficiency by means of performance 
orientation  and  accountability  mechanisms.  A  key  element  to  achieve  this  is  by  devolving 
financial and human resource responsibilities to heads of departments. It will enable a demand- 
driven and flexible service delivery to the general public and to the private sector in particular. In 
turn, this will improve public sentiments regarding the Government and its employees. Enforcing 
the established retirement age of 60 and offering voluntary retirement from age 50 will open up 
career prospects to younger public servants who otherwise would opt to migrate. These benefits 
will  offset  short-term  negative  social  impacts.    The  reforms  will  also  increase  economic 
resilience by reducing vulnerability to external circumstances created by the currently excessive 
dependence on overseas remittances and taxes on imported goods. 
 
B.  Risks 
 
76.  Political authority is highly centralized  in the King and the Cabinet, and the Government 
exerts a high degree of control over the economy.  The successful implementation of reform will 
require  considerable  and  sustained  political  will  to  (i)  delegate  an  increased  share  of 
management responsibilities to government departments within the reform framework; and (ii)  
create a transparent, consistent, and responsive policy environment. To date, such risks have 
been mitigated by the strong commitment of most senior government officials to push through 
the key policy reforms.  The Government’s establishment of a public-private sector consultative 
committee in 1998 was an acknowledgement of the importance of increased public participation 
in the decision-making process. Reform measures have been in preparation for some time, but 
until recently have not been acted upon by the Cabinet. Hence, they have not been placed 
before the Privy Council and the Parliament. The reform program is strongly supported by the 
Privy  Council.  The  Prime  Minister  and  the  minister  of  finance,  both  appointed  with  the 
endorsement of the Privy Council, were selected because of their recognized commitment to 
reform.  Over the past 2 years, the Privy Council has also approved several policy measures to 
improve the governance of PSEs and to lay the groundwork for corporatization and privatization.  
These  developments  indicate  that  the  proposed  reforms  are  supported  by  the  highest 
authorities in the country. 
 
77.  For the first time, Tonga is confronted with a situation that leaves the Government no 
option but to reform. The fast-deteriorating fiscal situation, the disappointing economic growth—
after the devastation caused by tropical cyclone Waka, GDP growth is now estimated to be 
below 1.5%—and, most critical, the disappearance of the safety net, the eroded Tonga Trust 
Fund,  have  together    shaped  the  necessary  specific  “macroeconomic  moment”  where 
macroeconomic  vulnerability  has  generated  broad-based  commitment  to  reform.    The 
Parliament  is  fully  aware  of  this  situation  and  is  expected  to  fully  support  the  proposed 
legislative reforms.  
 
78.  A major risk is that the Government may lack the capacity and management resources 
to implement some of the important reform measures, despite strong political will. The TA for 
building  a  performance-based  public  service  will  support  the  implementation  of  the  public 
service reform, and activities associated with the rightsizing of the public service. Assistance 
provided  by  AusAID  on  public  financial  management,  training  of  staff  in  the  Revenue

22  
Department, and the provision of two long-term advisors for tax and customs administration; 
PFTAC’s continuing support for  tax legislation and the tax reform;  and MFAT’s support to the 
GIU on commercialization and privatization of PSEs will all facilitate the timely implementation of 
the reform agenda.  
 
VIII.  ASSURANCES 
79.  In  addition  to  the  conditions  for  tranche  release  and  the  standard  assurances,  the 
Government has assured ADB that 
 
(i)  the policies adopted and actions taken prior to the date of the Loan Agreement, 
as described in the Government’s DPL, will continue in effect for the duration of 
the program period; 
 
(ii)  it will promptly adopt the other policies and take the other actions included in the 
EPSRP, as described in the policy matrix, and ensure that these policies and 
actions continue in effect for the duration of the EPSRP; 
 
(iii)  it will ensure adequate representation of women on committees, task forces, and 
other  public  bodies  dealing  with  the  building  of  a  performance-based  public 
service; and 
 
(iv)  it will ensure that the private sector and civil society groups are adequately 
involved in implementing the reforms through membership in task forces and 
committees dealing with reform issues.  
 
IX.  RECOMMENDATION 
80.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
ADB and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various currencies equivalent to 
Special Drawing Rights 8,020,000 to the Kingdom of Tonga for the Economic and Public Sector 
Reform Program from ADB’s Special Funds resources  with an interest charge at the rate of 1% 
per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum  thereafter;  a  term  of  24  years, 
including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the Board.

SOCIAL AND POVERTY IMPACT ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The social assessment is linked to the two major areas of the economic and public 
sector reform (EPSRP): (i) achievement of sustainable fiscal balance, and (ii) improvement of 
public service delivery to the private sector and the general public. A specialist1 in social impact 
assessments has evaluated the effects of policy changes under the EPSRP on the stakeholders 
and vulnerable groups, examined the current social security system, and assessed the social 
implications and poverty impact of the conditionalities under the EPSRP. The methods used for 
the social impact assessment included individual interviews and focus group discussions with a 
wide range of senior government officials and civil servants, private sector representatives, and 
civil society groups. Social monitoring and public consultation are a key element of the reform 
process. In addition, a Tongan participatory/public relations specialist (footnote 1) is assisting 
the  Government  in  a  broad-based  consultative  process  through  workshops  and  seminars, 
targeting specific groups (politicians, public sector officials, chamber of commerce, churches, 
and civil society groups) and hearings that bring together representatives of the Government, 
the business community, civil society groups, and the general public.  
 
B.  Socioeconomic Context 
2.  Population. The 1996 census recorded a population of 97,784. The total fertility rate 
was calculated at 4.2%, which, although high, has been offset by high emigration rates since the 
1970s; thus the average annual population growth rate since 1986 is low at 0.3% per annum. 
The number of Tongans living overseas was estimated to be between 35,000-45,000 in 1993 
and may now be considerably higher.2  
 
3.  Urbanization. There has been a massive shift from an agricultural subsistence-based 
economy to  substantial dependence on emigration, remittances, and public sector employment 
combined with increased urbanization. Sixty-eight percent of the population of Tongatapu, the 
most populous island in the group, live in the urban area of Nuku’alofa, and villages on the 
island are developing increasingly suburban characteristics.  The Government has recognized 
urban growth as an issue of concern since 1966, putting pressure on national resources for 
increased expenditure on physical infrastructure. Efforts continue to distribute services equitably 
between the rural and urban population. The provision of high schools in the outer islands  
(Ha’api group, Vava’u, Niuataputopu, and Niuafo’ou) aims to discourage rural-urban migration.  
 
4.  Despite extensive socioeconomic changes over the past 30 years, Tongan customs and 
traditions, the monarchy, the churches, and the extended family continue to be respected and 
emphasized and are all interconnected.  
   
5.  Human Development. The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) human 
development index ranks Tonga sixth out of 14 Pacific Island states.3 On a global scale Tonga 
is  ranked  107.  Tonga’s  relatively  high  ranking  arises  from  its  social  achievements  in  the 
provision of universal primary education, public health services, water, and sanitation, which 
have produced an almost universally literate population with average life expectancy of 67 years 
based on calculations in 1996. Although Tonga is encountering some social problems, and

6.  Gender. The gender equity and the status of women is higher in Tonga than in many 
other PDMCs in terms of women’s health status, participation rates in secondary education, and 
share of senior and middle management jobs. However, women have a smaller overall share of 
employment in the paid labor force.  There is gender disparity in tertiary qualifications. Although 
more  girls  than  boys  complete  secondary  education,  many  more  men  than  women  have 
technical and higher education qualifications. 
 
7.  There is significant legal discrimination against women with regard to property rights. 
Very few women have direct rights to own land, due to a patrilineal system of land allocation 
and inheritance adopted in the 19th century. Further, women are not permitted to legally register 
land in their own names.4 This affects women’s access to credit, as significant assets tend to be 
registered in the names of men.5 Indicative recent surveys6 suggest that more men than women 
in economically active age groups migrate. Accordingly women-headed households (19%  of all 
households in 1996) constitute a vulnerable group. There is concern that if the law gave every 
woman equal rights of inheritance with her brothers, control of portions of land might pass from 
the control of her own family and come under the control of her husband’s family. Although 
kainga (extended families) count both males and females as members by birth, and accord 
special respect to sisters and members of the female descent line, the control of family property 
is patrilineal. This fact has some influence on family decisions about educational investment in 
favor of males, although it is offset by the fact that families tend to invest in children who 
achieve well, irrespective of their gender.  
 
8.  Poverty. Among ADB’s 12 PDMCs, Tonga ranks first in the human poverty index. There 
are no recent household income and expenditure data on which firm conclusions about poverty 
can be based.7 In line with ADB’s new policy on poverty reduction, a preliminary poverty 
assessment was carried out under a regional technical assistance.8 The initial findings were 
compiled and circulated to the Government for comments. Additional data will be gathered for 
further assessment of the poverty situation in Tonga through a small-scale TA,9 which was 
approved in 2000, to assist the Government in conducting a household income and expenditure 
survey. The poor, in terms of national relativity, are those who suffer “poverty of opportunity” in 
relation to employment and other chances to improve their standards of living, particularly the 
youthful  majority.  Many  Tongans  live  in  overcrowded,  poor-quality  houses,  in  conditions 
conducive to social stress.

eligible10 to receive allotments of land exceed the provisions for land distribution under the

another to land if they need it for housing, to grow food, or to make a simple living. People of 
high traditional status have many privileges, not the least of which is access to land that returns 
rents of various kinds, but although Tonga is highly socially stratified, the gap between rich and 
poor is not as great as in many developing countries. 
 
11.  Social problems are considered to have increased along with the growth in the urban 
population. Physical assault and theft, including breaking and entering, are among the leading 
types of crime. Youth crime is not significant in Tonga, although there are growing concerns 
about delinquency in the urban area; most criminal acts are committed by persons aged 30-
35.11 Few data exist on domestic violence, which is included in police statistics with all types of 
assault,  but  it  is  a  recognized  social  problem.  A  recent  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund

having sustained one or more deliberate physical injuries in the previous 12 months, and about 
one third reported the injuries inflicted by one or both parents.12 The Catholic Women’s League 
has recently established a center for women and children to counter problems of domestic 
violence. 
 
12.  Social Safety Nets. There is no formal social security system for all citizens, although 
government  employees  in  established  positions  and  some  private  sector  employees  are 
covered by various retirement benefit arrangements. The Government has also agreed to the 
creation of a national retirement fund to provide for employees not covered by the government 
scheme.13 This will not provide a social safety net for its members until the fund grows over 
time. 
 
13.  The  Government  provides  for  general  public  welfare  by  allowing  extended  school 
attendance, low government school fees, and free government health services. Children are 
considered to have an obligation to support their parents in old age, and various kinds of mutual 
assistance mechanisms exist within families, although these are often severely strained by lack 
of financial resources.

16.  Remittances. Migrant relatives assist many households, but the relationship between 
island-based and overseas Tongans tends to be reciprocal. Children usually support or assist 
their parents or other relatives who raised them, whether they emigrate or remain in Tonga. 
Many working emigrant couples send children home, or leave them behind when they emigrate, 
to be taken care of by relatives. Taro and yam—these root crops are a stable diet for Tongans—

overseas communities, and are exchanged for consumer goods or money between island

17.  Money  is  often  sent  to  relatives  in  Tonga  by  emigrants,  not  to  support  everyday

Another “remittance” mechanism is short-term emigration, when people go overseas to work in 
order to earn a target sum to bring home for purposes such as building a house, or when groups 
go overseas to raise funds for special projects from emigrant communities. 
 
18.  The remittance-based economy depends on a continued flow of emigrants, as once 
migrants become established overseas, they usually buy or lease homes, raise families, and 
cannot afford to send much money home. Overseas-born Tongans are much less likely than 
first generation migrants to feel an obligation to send money to relatives in their ancestral land. 
The major source of remittances is from the United States.

employment service unit in the Ministry of Labor, Commerce and Industries registered 254 job 
seekers in 2000. Some young people registered but refused offers of employment for positions 
such as shop assistant because they aspired to clerical positions, preferably in the public 
service.

school level. The Government provides a primary school for every inhabited island with a

C.  Assessing the Impact of Reforms under the EPSRP 
23.  The EPSRP envisages (i) continuation of the existing freeze on new appointments to the 
public service, (ii) enforcement of the retirement age of 60, and (iii) provision of lump sum 
incentive payments to encourage employees over 50 to take early retirement. Currently, 79 
public servants in established posts are over 60 years, and 516 are over 50 years of age.16 
Public service regulations require retirement at age 60, but the rule is not enforced. It is not 
known how many government workers employed on a daily basis (752 in all) are in these age 
groups. Under the EPSRP, those positions that have been filled for long periods of time by 
employees on a daily basis will be established, so that the employees holding the posts will be 
entitled to pensions and early retirement benefits if they are in the eligible age groups.  
 
24.  A retirement fund for public servants covers workers in the public sector. Under the old 
pension scheme, employees had the option of retiring with a pension or a lump sum. The new 
scheme only provides lump sum payments. The Government has a liability of about T$30 million 
to the pension fund, which might constrain its ability to meet a sudden increase in demand for 
lump sum payments, as would occur if it rapidly downsized in the public service. Loan proceeds 
have been specially earmarked to cover retirement benefits and compensation payments.

26.  Vulnerable Groups. The major socioeconomic impact over the next 2 to 3 years is likely

27.  Research  conducted  by  the  Central  Planning  Department  (CPD)  under  the  Prime

not provide long-term social security for retirees. A survey of people, who had received cash

gave it away, repaid debts, or made an unsuccessful investment.  
 
28.  In households where the retrenched sole income earner is on a low salary scale and/or 
where the household has limited access to land, the hardship will be greatest. Lump sum 
pension payouts and severance payments will be made to public sector employees taking early 
retirement or who are made redundant, but the amount will be small for those who had held low-
wage positions.  A modest increase in those living below or close to the poverty line is a likely 
outcome.  
 
29.  Assuming that Tonga’s strong customs of family assistance will cushion the impact of 
reduced public sector expenditure and provide traditional social safety net functions, the high 
dependency ratio will continue to rise. Those in employment in Tonga will have increased 
financial obligations, and the demand on relatives working overseas will increase.

affected.

E.  Mitigation Measures 
 
34.  In  addition  to  financial  compensation  packages  for  voluntary  early  retirees  and 
redundancies, a range of nonfinancial mitigation measures will be available. It is likely that up to 
500 people will opt for training as part of a retirement/redundancy package over 3 years. The 
economic and social impact monitoring unit will establish the training needs of early retirees and 
retrenched public servants. It is anticipated that training requirements will focus on four areas: (i) 
small business management; (ii) farm management with technical agricultural content; (iii) basic 
accounting and bookkeeping; and (iv) computer applications, office management, and office 
automation.  
 
35.  To be effective, courses should last approximately 16 weeks. It is estimated that the 
number of people eligible for retraining will be around 500. The cost is estimated at around 
US$500 per person, assuming that courses are offered by local providers or by the University of 
the South Pacific (USP). Following on these estimates, if 500 people were trained, the total cost 
would be around US$250,000. A training allowance in the range of US$50 per week of training 
will be considered.  
 
36.  Pension payouts and compensation packages are paid in lump sums. Prudent financial 
management  practices  will  be  needed  to  make  these  funds  last.  The  objective  of  person 
financial management training is to avoid poverty and ensure public welfare through a more 
effective use of family income. This will be achieved through a training and awareness program 
that will involve both rural and urban families throughout the country. Because of cultural factors 
and customary communal obligations and pressures, targeting only those who will be leaving 
public service employment will not be effective. It will be necessary to achieve a broad-based 
understanding among the families of people leaving government employment, and the general 
public as well, of how improved financial management at the household level can avoid poverty 
and increase social security.

A.  Background and Rationale 
 
1.  A  major  part  of  the  Government’s  policy  reform  program  is  the  initiative  to  build  a 
performance-based public service. The need for public service reform has long been recognized. 
Public service reform committees were established in 2000 and have reported on (i) the core 
functions of the Government as prescribed by existing laws and regulations, (ii) a plan for public 
service reform, and (iii) means of implementation. The task for the Government is to formulate an 
implementation plan of sequenced and meaningful policy actions that is commensurate with 
administrative capacity. Public service reform is aimed at reducing the size and costs of the public 
service while maintaining and improving service delivery. Its successful implementation is crucial 
to  fiscal  balance,  improved  governance,  and  effective  economic  policy  reform.  The  Prime 
Minister’s Office (PMO) is responsible for the formulation and implementation of public service 
reform. However, the Government needs to build its capacity to manage the public service reform, 
including monitoring of the impact of the reform measures.  
 
B.  The Technical Assistance 
 
1.  Objective and Scope  
 
2.  The overall public service reform seeks to improve public service delivery to the private 
sector and the general public. The technical assistance (TA) will support this overall goal. It has 
as  its  objective  to  build  a  performance-oriented  public  service  through  (i)  establishing  the 
institutional framework for a performance-oriented public service, and (ii) promoting efficient and 
effective performance management. The TA will (i) facilitate good governance practices and 
strengthen the planning, monitoring, and reporting capabilities of all ministries; (ii) establish the 
central human resource management information system (HRMIS) to provide users with timely, 
accurate and relevant establishment information; (iii) introduce performance accountability for 
heads of departments; (iv) support the introduction of performance-oriented and merit-based 
remuneration policies and procedures; and (v) assist in the preparation of regulations and 
implementation guidelines  for new legislation under the Economic and Public Sector Reform 
Program  (EPSRP).  The  TA  will  cooperate  closely  with  the  assistance  provided  for  the 
establishment of a public service commission by the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs 
and Trade.   
 
  2.  Costs and Financing

exchange cost of US$676,000 and a local currency cost of US$164,000 equivalent. The Asian

exchange cost and US$24,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. Financing will come from the
